The ad claims that Newark has a 13 perce: which was verified by comparing unemployment data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics for the time period of February 2010 to February 2013 and May 2010 to May 2013. The unemployment rates for Newark during these time frames were found to range between 14.3 percent and nearly 16.5 percent, confirming that the claim of 13 percent unemployment is inaccurate.
The expert: s verdict mentions that the unemployment data reviewed was not seasonally adjusted, and it was advised to use the same month to compare data from different years. This aspect ensures that the comparison of unemployment rates is done accurately and eliminates any seasonal variations that could affect the results.
The methodology used to determine Newark: s unemployment rate was confirmed to be correct by a spokesperson from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. This aspect adds credibility to the verification process and ensures that the correct calculations and analysis were performed.
Additionally: the comparison of May unemployment rates in Newark for 2010 and 2013 was conducted. The unemployment rate in May 2010 was found to be 15.1 percent, while the preliminary rate for May 2013 was 13.7 percent. This aspect further supports the conclusion that the claim of 13 percent unemployment in Newark is inaccurate.
